1.verse: Dear friend who loves God: Several biographies of Christ have already been written using as their source material the reports circulating among us from the early disciples and other eyewitnesses.

2.verse: Dear friend who loves God: Several biographies of Christ have already been written using as their source material the reports circulating among us from the early disciples and other eyewitnesses.

3.verse: However, it occurred to me that it would be well to recheck all these accounts from first to last and after thorough investigation to pass this summary on to you,

4.verse: to reassure you of the truth of all you were taught.

5.verse: My story begins with a Jewish priest, Zacharias, who lived when Herod was king of Judea. Zacharias was a member of the Abijah division of the Temple service corps. (His wife, Elizabeth, was, like himself, a member of the priest tribe of the Jews, a descendant of Aaron.)

6.verse: Zacharias and Elizabeth were godly folk, careful to obey all of God’s laws in spirit as well as in letter.

7.verse: But they had no children, for Elizabeth was barren; and now they were both very old.

8.verse: One day as Zacharias was going about his work in the Temple—for his division was on duty that week—the honor fell to him by lot to enter the inner sanctuary and burn incense before the Lord.

9.verse: One day as Zacharias was going about his work in the Temple—for his division was on duty that week—the honor fell to him by lot to enter the inner sanctuary and burn incense before the Lord.

10.verse: Meanwhile, a great crowd stood outside in the Temple court, praying as they always did during that part of the service when the incense was being burned.

11.verse: Zacharias was in the sanctuary when suddenly an angel appeared, standing to the right of the altar of incense! Zacharias was startled and terrified.

12.verse: Zacharias was in the sanctuary when suddenly an angel appeared, standing to the right of the altar of incense! Zacharias was startled and terrified.

13.verse: But the angel said, “Don’t be afraid, Zacharias! For I have come to tell you that God has heard your prayer, and your wife, Elizabeth, will bear you a son! And you are to name him John.

14.verse: You will both have great joy and gladness at his birth, and many will rejoice with you.

15.verse: For he will be one of the Lord’s great men. He must never touch wine or hard liquor—and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit, even from before his birth!

16.verse: And he will persuade many a Jew to turn to the Lord his God.

17.verse: He will be a man of rugged spirit and power like Elijah, the prophet of old; and he will precede the coming of the Messiah, preparing the people for his arrival. He will soften adult hearts to become like little children’s, and will change disobedient minds to the wisdom of faith.”*

18.verse: Zacharias said to the angel, “But this is impossible! I’m an old man now, and my wife is also well along in years.”

19.verse: Then the angel said, “I am Gabriel! I stand in the very presence of God. It was he who sent me to you with this good news!

20.verse: And now, because you haven’t believed me, you are to be stricken silent, unable to speak until the child is born. For my words will certainly come true at the proper time.”

21.verse: Meanwhile the crowds outside were waiting for Zacharias to appear and wondered why he was taking so long.

22.verse: When he finally came out, he couldn’t speak to them, and they realized from his gestures that he must have seen a vision in the Temple.

23.verse: He stayed on at the Temple for the remaining days of his Temple duties and then returned home.

24.verse: Soon afterwards Elizabeth his wife became pregnant and went into seclusion for five months.

25.verse: “How kind the Lord is,” she exclaimed, “to take away my disgrace of having no children!”

26.verse: The following month God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a village in Galilee,

27.verse: to a virgin, Mary, engaged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of King David.

28.verse: Gabriel appeared to her and said, “Congratulations, favored lady! The Lord is with you!”

29.verse: Confused and disturbed, Mary tried to think what the angel could mean.

30.verse: “Don’t be frightened, Mary,” the angel told her, “for God has decided to wonderfully bless you!

31.verse: Very soon now, you will become pregnant and have a baby boy, and you are to name him ‘Jesus.’

32.verse: He shall be very great and shall be called the Son of God. And the Lord God shall give him the throne of his ancestor David.

33.verse: And he shall reign over Israel forever; his Kingdom shall never end!”

34.verse: Mary asked the angel, “But how can I have a baby? I am a virgin.”

35.verse: The angel replied, “The Holy Spirit shall come upon you, and the power of God shall overshadow you; so the baby born to you will be utterly holy—the Son of God.

36.verse: Furthermore, six months ago your Aunt Elizabeth—‘the barren one,’ they called her—became pregnant in her old age!

37.verse: For every promise from God shall surely come true.”

38.verse: Mary said, “I am the Lord’s servant, and I am willing to do whatever he wants. May everything you said come true.” And then the angel disappeared.

39.verse: A few days later Mary hurried to the highlands of Judea to the town where Zacharias lived, to visit Elizabeth.

40.verse: A few days later Mary hurried to the highlands of Judea to the town where Zacharias lived, to visit Elizabeth.

41.verse: At the sound of Mary’s greeting, Elizabeth’s child leaped within her and she was filled with the Holy Spirit.

42.verse: She gave a glad cry and exclaimed to Mary, “You are favored by God above all other women, and your child is destined for God’s mightiest praise.

43.verse: What an honor this is, that the mother of my Lord should visit me!

44.verse: When you came in and greeted me, the instant I heard your voice, my baby moved in me for joy!

45.verse: You believed that God would do what he said; that is why he has given you this wonderful blessing.”

46.verse: Mary responded, “Oh, how I praise the Lord.

47.verse: How I rejoice in God my Savior!

48.verse: For he took notice of his lowly servant girl, and now generation after generation forever shall call me blest of God.

49.verse: For he, the mighty Holy One, has done great things to me.

50.verse: His mercy goes on from generation to generation, to all who reverence him.

51.verse: “How powerful is his mighty arm! How he scatters the proud and haughty ones!

52.verse: He has torn princes from their thrones and exalted the lowly.

53.verse: He has satisfied the hungry hearts and sent the rich away with empty hands.

54.verse: And how he has helped his servant Israel! He has not forgotten his promise to be merciful.

55.verse: For he promised our fathers—Abraham and his children—to be merciful to them forever.”

56.verse: Mary stayed with Elizabeth about three months and then went back to her own home.

57.verse: By now Elizabeth’s waiting was over, for the time had come for the baby to be born—and it was a boy.

58.verse: The word spread quickly to her neighbors and relatives of how kind the Lord had been to her, and everyone rejoiced.

59.verse: When the baby was eight days old, all the relatives and friends came for the circumcision ceremony. They all assumed the baby’s name would be Zacharias, after his father.

60.verse: But Elizabeth said, “No! He must be named John!”

61.verse: “What?” they exclaimed. “There is no one in all your family by that name.”

62.verse: So they asked the baby’s father, talking to him by gestures.

63.verse: He motioned for a piece of paper and to everyone’s surprise wrote, “His name is John!”

64.verse: Instantly Zacharias could speak again, and he began praising God.

65.verse: Wonder fell upon the whole neighborhood, and the news of what had happened spread through the Judean hills.

66.verse: And everyone who heard about it thought long thoughts and asked, “I wonder what this child will turn out to be? For the hand of the Lord is surely upon him in some special way.”

67.verse: Then his father, Zacharias, was filled with the Holy Spirit and gave this prophecy:

68.verse: “Praise the Lord, the God of Israel, for he has come to visit his people and has redeemed them.

69.verse: He is sending us a Mighty Savior from the royal line of his servant David,

70.verse: just as he promised through his holy prophets long ago—

71.verse: someone to save us from our enemies, from all who hate us.

72.verse: “He has been merciful to our ancestors, yes, to Abraham himself, by remembering his sacred promise to him,

73.verse: “He has been merciful to our ancestors, yes, to Abraham himself, by remembering his sacred promise to him,

74.verse: and by granting us the privilege of serving God fearlessly, freed from our enemies,

75.verse: and by making us holy and acceptable, ready to stand in his presence forever.

76.verse: “And you, my little son, shall be called the prophet of the glorious God, for you will prepare the way for the Messiah.

77.verse: You will tell his people how to find salvation through forgiveness of their sins.

78.verse: All this will be because the mercy of our God is very tender, and heaven’s dawn is about to break upon us,

79.verse: to give light to those who sit in darkness and death’s shadow, and to guide us to the path of peace.”

80.verse: The little boy greatly loved God and when he grew up he lived out in the lonely wilderness until he began his public ministry to Israel.

1.verse: About this time Caesar Augustus, the Roman emperor, decreed that a census should be taken throughout the nation.

2.verse: (This census was taken when Quirinius was governor of Syria.)

3.verse: Everyone was required to return to his ancestral home for this registration.

4.verse: And because Joseph was a member of the royal line, he had to go to Bethlehem in Judea, King David’s ancient home—journeying there from the Galilean village of Nazareth.

5.verse: He took with him Mary, his fiancée, who was obviously pregnant by this time.

6.verse: And while they were there, the time came for her baby to be born;

7.verse: and she gave birth to her first child, a son. She wrapped him in a blanket and laid him in a manger, because there was no room for them in the village inn.

8.verse: That night some shepherds were in the fields outside the village, guarding their flocks of sheep.

9.verse: Suddenly an angel appeared among them, and the landscape shone bright with the glory of the Lord. They were badly frightened,

10.verse: but the angel reassured them. “Don’t be afraid!” he said. “I bring you the most joyful news ever announced, and it is for everyone!

11.verse: The Savior—yes, the Messiah, the Lord—has been born tonight in Bethlehem!

12.verse: How will you recognize him? You will find a baby wrapped in a blanket, lying in a manger!”

13.verse: Suddenly, the angel was joined by a vast host of others—the armies of heaven—praising God:

14.verse: “Glory to God in the highest heaven,” they sang, “and peace on earth for all those pleasing him.”

15.verse: When this great army of angels had returned again to heaven, the shepherds said to each other, “Come on! Let’s go to Bethlehem! Let’s see this wonderful thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.”

16.verse: They ran to the village and found their way to Mary and Joseph. And there was the baby, lying in the manger.

17.verse: The shepherds told everyone what had happened and what the angel had said to them about this child.

18.verse: All who heard the shepherds’ story expressed astonishment,

19.verse: but Mary quietly treasured these things in her heart and often thought about them.

20.verse: Then the shepherds went back again to their fields and flocks, praising God for the visit of the angels, and because they had seen the child, just as the angel had told them.

21.verse: Eight days later, at the baby’s circumcision ceremony, he was named Jesus, the name given him by the angel before he was even conceived.

22.verse: When the time came for Mary’s purification offering at the Temple, as required by the laws of Moses after the birth of a child, his parents took him to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord;

23.verse: for in these laws God had said, “If a woman’s first child is a boy, he shall be dedicated to the Lord.”

24.verse: At that time Jesus’ parents also offered their sacrifice for purification—“either a pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons” was the legal requirement.

25.verse: That day a man named Simeon, a Jerusalem resident, was in the Temple. He was a good man, very devout, filled with the Holy Spirit and constantly expecting the Messiah to come soon.

26.verse: For the Holy Spirit had revealed to him that he would not die until he had seen him—God’s anointed King.

27.verse: The Holy Spirit had impelled him to go to the Temple that day; and so, when Mary and Joseph arrived to present the baby Jesus to the Lord in obedience to the law,

28.verse: Simeon was there and took the child in his arms, praising God.

29.verse: “Lord,” he said, “now I can die content! For I have seen him as you promised me I would. I have seen the Savior you have given to the world.

30.verse: “Lord,” he said, “now I can die content! For I have seen him as you promised me I would. I have seen the Savior you have given to the world.

31.verse: “Lord,” he said, “now I can die content! For I have seen him as you promised me I would. I have seen the Savior you have given to the world.

32.verse: He is the Light that will shine upon the nations, and he will be the glory of your people Israel!”

33.verse: Joseph and Mary just stood there, marveling at what was being said about Jesus.

34.verse: Simeon blessed them but then said to Mary, “A sword shall pierce your soul, for this child shall be rejected by many in Israel, and this to their undoing. But he will be the greatest joy of many others. And the deepest thoughts of many hearts shall be revealed.”

35.verse: Simeon blessed them but then said to Mary, “A sword shall pierce your soul, for this child shall be rejected by many in Israel, and this to their undoing. But he will be the greatest joy of many others. And the deepest thoughts of many hearts shall be revealed.”

36.verse: Anna, a prophetess, was also there in the Temple that day. She was the daughter of Phanuel, of the Jewish tribe of Asher, and was very old, for she had been a widow for eighty-four years following seven years of marriage. She never left the Temple but stayed there night and day, worshiping God by praying and often fasting.

37.verse: Anna, a prophetess, was also there in the Temple that day. She was the daughter of Phanuel, of the Jewish tribe of Asher, and was very old, for she had been a widow for eighty-four years following seven years of marriage. She never left the Temple but stayed there night and day, worshiping God by praying and often fasting.

38.verse: She came along just as Simeon was talking with Mary and Joseph, and she also began thanking God and telling everyone in Jerusalem who had been awaiting the coming of the Savior that the Messiah had finally arrived.

39.verse: When Jesus’ parents had fulfilled all the requirements of the Law of God, they returned home to Nazareth in Galilee.

40.verse: There the child became a strong, robust lad, and was known for wisdom beyond his years; and God poured out his blessings on him.

41.verse: When Jesus was twelve years old, he accompanied his parents to Jerusalem for the annual Passover Festival, which they attended each year.

42.verse: When Jesus was twelve years old, he accompanied his parents to Jerusalem for the annual Passover Festival, which they attended each year.

43.verse: After the celebration was over they started home to Nazareth, but Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem. His parents didn’t miss him the first day,

44.verse: for they assumed he was with friends among the other travelers. But when he didn’t show up that evening, they started to look for him among their relatives and friends;

45.verse: and when they couldn’t find him, they went back to Jerusalem to search for him there.

46.verse: Three days later they finally discovered him. He was in the Temple, sitting among the teachers of Law, discussing deep questions with them and amazing everyone with his understanding and answers.

47.verse: Three days later they finally discovered him. He was in the Temple, sitting among the teachers of Law, discussing deep questions with them and amazing everyone with his understanding and answers.

48.verse: His parents didn’t know what to think. “Son!” his mother said to him. “Why have you done this to us? Your father and I have been frantic, searching for you everywhere.”

49.verse: “But why did you need to search?” he asked. “Didn’t you realize that I would be here at the Temple, in my Father’s House?”

50.verse: But they didn’t understand what he meant.

51.verse: Then he returned to Nazareth with them and was obedient to them; and his mother stored away all these things in her heart.

52.verse: So Jesus grew both tall and wise, and was loved by God and man.

1.verse: In the fifteenth year of the reign of Emperor Tiberius Caesar, a message came from God to John (the son of Zacharias), as he was living out in the deserts. (Pilate was governor over Judea at that time; Herod, over Galilee; his brother Philip, over Iturea and Trachonitis; Lysanias, over Abilene; and Annas and Caiaphas were high priests.)

2.verse: In the fifteenth year of the reign of Emperor Tiberius Caesar, a message came from God to John (the son of Zacharias), as he was living out in the deserts. (Pilate was governor over Judea at that time; Herod, over Galilee; his brother Philip, over Iturea and Trachonitis; Lysanias, over Abilene; and Annas and Caiaphas were high priests.)

3.verse: Then John went from place to place on both sides of the Jordan River, preaching that people should be baptized to show that they had turned to God and away from their sins, in order to be forgiven.

4.verse: In the words of Isaiah the prophet, John was “a voice shouting from the barren wilderness, ‘Prepare a road for the Lord to travel on! Widen the pathway before him!

5.verse: Level the mountains! Fill up the valleys! Straighten the curves! Smooth out the ruts!

6.verse: And then all mankind shall see the Savior sent from God.’”

7.verse: Here is a sample of John’s preaching to the crowds that came for baptism: “You brood of snakes! You are trying to escape hell without truly turning to God! That is why you want to be baptized!

8.verse: First go and prove by the way you live that you really have repented. And don’t think you are safe because you are descendants of Abraham. That isn’t enough. God can produce children of Abraham from these desert stones!

9.verse: The ax of his judgment is poised over you, ready to sever your roots and cut you down. Yes, every tree that does not produce good fruit will be chopped down and thrown into the fire.”

10.verse: The crowd replied, “What do you want us to do?”

11.verse: “If you have two coats,” he replied, “give one to the poor. If you have extra food, give it away to those who are hungry.”

12.verse: Even tax collectors—notorious for their corruption—came to be baptized and asked, “How shall we prove to you that we have abandoned our sins?”

13.verse: “By your honesty,” he replied. “Make sure you collect no more taxes than the Roman government requires you to.”

14.verse: “And us,” asked some soldiers, “what about us?” John replied, “Don’t extort money by threats and violence; don’t accuse anyone of what you know he didn’t do; and be content with your pay!”

15.verse: Everyone was expecting the Messiah to come soon, and eager to know whether or not John was he. This was the question of the hour and was being discussed everywhere.

16.verse: John answered the question by saying, “I baptize only with water; but someone is coming soon who has far higher authority than mine; in fact, I am not even worthy of being his slave. He will baptize you with fire—with the Holy Spirit.

17.verse: He will separate chaff from grain, and burn up the chaff with eternal fire and store away the grain.”

18.verse: He used many such warnings as he announced the Good News to the people.

19.verse: (But after John had publicly criticized Herod, governor of Galilee, for marrying Herodias, his brother’s wife, and for many other wrongs he had done, Herod put John in prison, thus adding this sin to all his many others.)

20.verse: (But after John had publicly criticized Herod, governor of Galilee, for marrying Herodias, his brother’s wife, and for many other wrongs he had done, Herod put John in prison, thus adding this sin to all his many others.)

21.verse: Then one day, after the crowds had been baptized, Jesus himself was baptized; and as he was praying, the heavens opened,

22.verse: and the Holy Spirit in the form of a dove settled upon him, and a voice from heaven said, “You are my much loved Son, yes, my delight.”

23.verse: Jesus was about thirty years old when he began his public ministry. Jesus was known as the son of Joseph. Joseph’s father was Heli; Heli’s father was Matthat; Matthat’s father was Levi; Levi’s father was Melchi; Melchi’s father was Jannai; Jannai’s father was Joseph; Joseph’s father was Mattathias; Mattathias’s father was Amos; Amos’s father was Nahum; Nahum’s father was Esli; Esli’s father was Naggai; Naggai’s father was Maath; Maath’s father was Mattathias; Mattathias’s father was Semein; Semein’s father was Josech; Josech’s father was Joda; Joda’s father was Joanan; Joanan’s father was Rhesa; Rhesa’s father was Zerubbabel; Zerubbabel’s father was Shealtiel; Shealtiel’s father was Neri; Neri’s father was Melchi; Melchi’s father was Addi; Addi’s father was Cosam; Cosam’s father was Elmadam; Elmadam’s father was Er; Er’s father was Joshua; Joshua’s father was Eliezer; Eliezer’s father was Jorim; Jorim’s father was Matthat; Matthat’s father was Levi; 1.verse: Then Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, left the Jordan River, being urged by the Spirit out into the barren wastelands of Judea, where Satan tempted him for forty days. He ate nothing all that time and was very hungry.

2.verse: Then Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, left the Jordan River, being urged by the Spirit out into the barren wastelands of Judea, where Satan tempted him for forty days. He ate nothing all that time and was very hungry.

3.verse: Satan said, “If you are God’s Son, tell this stone to become a loaf of bread.”

4.verse: But Jesus replied, “It is written in the Scriptures, ‘Other things in life are much more important than bread!’”

5.verse: Then Satan took him up and revealed to him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time;

6.verse: and the devil told him, “I will give you all these splendid kingdoms and their glory—for they are mine to give to anyone I wish—if you will only get down on your knees and worship me.”

7.verse: and the devil told him, “I will give you all these splendid kingdoms and their glory—for they are mine to give to anyone I wish—if you will only get down on your knees and worship me.”

8.verse: Jesus replied, “We must worship God, and him alone. So it is written in the Scriptures.”

9.verse: Then Satan took him to Jerusalem to a high roof of the Temple and said, “If you are the Son of God, jump off! For the Scriptures say that God will send his angels to guard you and to keep you from crashing to the pavement below!”

10.verse: Then Satan took him to Jerusalem to a high roof of the Temple and said, “If you are the Son of God, jump off! For the Scriptures say that God will send his angels to guard you and to keep you from crashing to the pavement below!”

11.verse: Then Satan took him to Jerusalem to a high roof of the Temple and said, “If you are the Son of God, jump off! For the Scriptures say that God will send his angels to guard you and to keep you from crashing to the pavement below!”

12.verse: Jesus replied, “The Scriptures also say, ‘Do not put the Lord your God to a foolish test.’”

13.verse: When the devil had ended all the temptations, he left Jesus for a while and went away.

14.verse: Then Jesus returned to Galilee, full of the Holy Spirit’s power. Soon he became well known throughout all that region

15.verse: for his sermons in the synagogues; everyone praised him.

16.verse: When he came to the village of Nazareth, his boyhood home, he went as usual to the synagogue on Saturday, and stood up to read the Scriptures.

17.verse: The book of Isaiah the prophet was handed to him, and he opened it to the place where it says:

18.verse: “The Spirit of the Lord is upon me; he has appointed me to preach Good News to the poor; he has sent me to heal the brokenhearted and to announce that captives shall be released and the blind shall see, that the downtrodden shall be freed from their oppressors, and that God is ready to give blessings to all who come to him.”

19.verse: “The Spirit of the Lord is upon me; he has appointed me to preach Good News to the poor; he has sent me to heal the brokenhearted and to announce that captives shall be released and the blind shall see, that the downtrodden shall be freed from their oppressors, and that God is ready to give blessings to all who come to him.”

20.verse: He closed the book and handed it back to the attendant and sat down, while everyone in the synagogue gazed at him intently.

21.verse: Then he added, “These Scriptures came true today!”

22.verse: All who were there spoke well of him and were amazed by the beautiful words that fell from his lips. “How can this be?” they asked. “Isn’t this Joseph’s son?”

23.verse: Then he said, “Probably you will quote me that proverb, ‘Physician, heal yourself’—meaning, ‘Why don’t you do miracles here in your hometown like those you did in Capernaum?’

24.verse: But I solemnly declare to you that no prophet is accepted in his own hometown!

25.verse: For example, remember how Elijah the prophet used a miracle to help the widow of Zarephath—a foreigner from the land of Sidon. There were many Jewish widows needing help in those days of famine, for there had been no rain for three and a half years, and hunger stalked the land; yet Elijah was not sent to them.

26.verse: For example, remember how Elijah the prophet used a miracle to help the widow of Zarephath—a foreigner from the land of Sidon. There were many Jewish widows needing help in those days of famine, for there had been no rain for three and a half years, and hunger stalked the land; yet Elijah was not sent to them.

27.verse: Or think of the prophet Elisha, who healed Naaman, a Syrian, rather than the many Jewish lepers needing help.”

28.verse: These remarks stung them to fury;

29.verse: and jumping up, they mobbed him and took him to the edge of the hill on which the city was built, to push him over the cliff.

30.verse: But he walked away through the crowd and left them.

31.verse: Then he returned to Capernaum, a city in Galilee, and preached there in the synagogue every Saturday.

32.verse: Here, too, the people were amazed at the things he said. For he spoke as one who knew the truth, instead of merely quoting the opinions of others as his authority.

33.verse: Once as he was teaching in the synagogue, a man possessed by a demon began shouting at Jesus,

34.verse: “Go away! We want nothing to do with you, Jesus from Nazareth. You have come to destroy us. I know who you are—the Holy Son of God.”

35.verse: Jesus cut him short. “Be silent!” he told the demon. “Come out!” The demon threw the man to the floor as the crowd watched, and then left him without hurting him further.

36.verse: Amazed, the people asked, “What is in this man’s words that even demons obey him?”

37.verse: The story of what he had done spread like wildfire throughout the whole region.

38.verse: After leaving the synagogue that day, he went to Simon’s home where he found Simon’s mother-in-law very sick with a high fever. “Please heal her,” everyone begged.

39.verse: Standing at her bedside he spoke to the fever, rebuking it, and immediately her temperature returned to normal, and she got up and prepared a meal for them!

40.verse: As the sun went down that evening, all the villagers who had any sick people in their homes, no matter what their diseases were, brought them to Jesus; and the touch of his hands healed every one!

41.verse: Some were possessed by demons; and the demons came out at his command, shouting, “You are the Son of God.” But because they knew he was the Christ, he stopped them and told them to be silent.

42.verse: Early the next morning he went out into the desert. The crowds searched everywhere for him, and when they finally found him, they begged him not to leave them but to stay at Capernaum.

43.verse: But he replied, “I must preach the Good News of the Kingdom of God in other places too, for that is why I was sent.”

44.verse: So he continued to travel around preaching in synagogues throughout Judea.

1.verse: One day as he was preaching on the shore of Lake Gennesaret, great crowds pressed in on him to listen to the Word of God.

2.verse: He noticed two empty boats standing at the water’s edge while the fishermen washed their nets.

3.verse: Stepping into one of the boats, Jesus asked Simon, its owner, to push out a little into the water, so that he could sit in the boat and speak to the crowds from there.

4.verse: When he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, “Now go out where it is deeper and let down your nets and you will catch a lot of fish!”

5.verse: “Sir,” Simon replied, “we worked hard all last night and didn’t catch a thing. But if you say so, we’ll try again.”

6.verse: And this time their nets were so full that they began to tear!

7.verse: A shout for help brought their partners in the other boat, and soon both boats were filled with fish and on the verge of sinking.

8.verse: When Simon Peter realized what had happened, he fell to his knees before Jesus and said, “Oh, sir, please leave us—I’m too much of a sinner for you to have around.”

9.verse: For he was awestruck by the size of their catch, as were the others with him,

10.verse: and his partners too—James and John, the sons of Zebedee. Jesus replied, “Don’t be afraid! From now on you’ll be fishing for the souls of men!”

11.verse: And as soon as they landed, they left everything and went with him.

12.verse: One day in a certain village he was visiting, there was a man with an advanced case of leprosy. When he saw Jesus, he fell to the ground before him, face downward in the dust, begging to be healed. “Sir,” he said, “if you only will, you can clear me of every trace of my disease.”

13.verse: Jesus reached out and touched the man and said, “Of course I will. Be healed.” And the leprosy left him instantly!

14.verse: Then Jesus instructed him to go at once without telling anyone what had happened and be examined by the Jewish priest. “Offer the sacrifice Moses’ law requires for lepers who are healed,” he said. “This will prove to everyone that you are well.”

15.verse: Now the report of his power spread even faster and vast crowds came to hear him preach and to be healed of their diseases.

16.verse: But he often withdrew to the wilderness for prayer.

17.verse: One day while he was teaching, some Jewish religious leaders and teachers of the Law were sitting nearby. (It seemed that these men showed up from every village in all Galilee and Judea, as well as from Jerusalem.) And the Lord’s healing power was upon him.

18.verse: Then—look! Some men came carrying a paralyzed man on a sleeping mat. They tried to push through the crowd to Jesus but couldn’t reach him. So they went up on the roof above him, took off some tiles, and lowered the sick man down into the crowd, still on his sleeping mat, right in front of Jesus.

19.verse: Then—look! Some men came carrying a paralyzed man on a sleeping mat. They tried to push through the crowd to Jesus but couldn’t reach him. So they went up on the roof above him, took off some tiles, and lowered the sick man down into the crowd, still on his sleeping mat, right in front of Jesus.

20.verse: Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the man, “My friend, your sins are forgiven!”

21.verse: “Who does this fellow think he is?” the Pharisees and teachers of the Law exclaimed among themselves. “This is blasphemy! Who but God can forgive sins?”

22.verse: Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he replied, “Why is it blasphemy?

23.verse: I, the Messiah, have the authority on earth to forgive sins. But talk is cheap—anybody could say that. So I’ll prove it to you by healing this man.” Then, turning to the paralyzed man, he commanded, “Pick up your stretcher and go on home, for you are healed!”

24.verse: I, the Messiah, have the authority on earth to forgive sins. But talk is cheap—anybody could say that. So I’ll prove it to you by healing this man.” Then, turning to the paralyzed man, he commanded, “Pick up your stretcher and go on home, for you are healed!”

25.verse: And immediately, as everyone watched, the man jumped to his feet, picked up his mat and went home praising God!

26.verse: Everyone present was gripped with awe and fear. And they praised God, remarking over and over again, “We have seen strange things today.”

27.verse: Later on as Jesus left the town he saw a tax collector—with the usual reputation for cheating—sitting at a tax collection booth. The man’s name was Levi. Jesus said to him, “Come and be one of my disciples!”

28.verse: So Levi left everything, sprang up, and went with him.

29.verse: Soon Levi held a reception in his home with Jesus as the guest of honor. Many of Levi’s fellow tax collectors and other guests were there.

30.verse: But the Pharisees and teachers of the Law complained bitterly to Jesus’ disciples about his eating with such notorious sinners.

31.verse: Jesus answered them, “It is the sick who need a doctor, not those in good health.

32.verse: My purpose is to invite sinners to turn from their sins, not to spend my time with those who think themselves already good enough.”

33.verse: Their next complaint was that Jesus’ disciples were feasting instead of fasting. “John the Baptist’s disciples are constantly going without food and praying,” they declared, “and so do the disciples of the Pharisees. Why are yours wining and dining?”

34.verse: Jesus asked, “Do happy men fast? Do wedding guests go hungry while celebrating with the groom?

35.verse: But the time will come when the bridegroom will be killed; then they won’t want to eat.”

36.verse: Then Jesus used this illustration: “No one tears off a piece of a new garment to make a patch for an old one. Not only will the new garment be ruined, but the old garment will look worse with a new patch on it!

37.verse: And no one puts new wine into old wineskins, for the new wine bursts the old skins, ruining the skins and spilling the wine.

38.verse: New wine must be put into new wineskins.

39.verse: But no one after drinking the old wine seems to want the fresh and the new. ‘The old ways are best,’ they say.”

1.verse: One Sabbath as Jesus and his disciples were walking through some grainfields, they were breaking off the heads of wheat, rubbing off the husks in their hands and eating the grains.

2.verse: But some Pharisees said, “That’s illegal! Your disciples are harvesting grain, and it’s against the Jewish law to work on the Sabbath.”

3.verse: Jesus replied, “Don’t you read the Scriptures? Haven’t you ever read what King David did when he and his men were hungry?

4.verse: He went into the Temple and took the shewbread, the special bread that was placed before the Lord, and ate it—illegal as this was—and shared it with others.”

5.verse: And Jesus added, “I am master even of the Sabbath.”

6.verse: On another Sabbath he was in the synagogue teaching, and a man was present whose right hand was deformed.

7.verse: The teachers of the Law and the Pharisees watched closely to see whether he would heal the man that day, since it was the Sabbath. For they were eager to find some charge to bring against him.

8.verse: How well he knew their thoughts! But he said to the man with the deformed hand, “Come and stand here where everyone can see.” So he did.

9.verse: Then Jesus said to the Pharisees and teachers of the Law, “I have a question for you. Is it right to do good on the Sabbath day, or to do harm? To save life, or to destroy it?”

10.verse: He looked around at them one by one and then said to the man, “Reach out your hand.” And as he did, it became completely normal again.

11.verse: At this, the enemies of Jesus were wild with rage and began to plot his murder.

12.verse: One day soon afterwards he went out into the mountains to pray, and prayed all night.

13.verse: At daybreak he called together his followers and chose twelve of them to be the inner circle of his disciples. (They were appointed as his “apostles,” or “missionaries.”)

14.verse: Here are their names: Simon (he also called him Peter), Andrew (Simon’s brother), James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James (the son of Alphaeus), Simon (a member of the Zealots, a subversive political party), Judas (son of James), Judas Iscariot (who later betrayed him).

15.verse: Here are their names: Simon (he also called him Peter), Andrew (Simon’s brother), James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James (the son of Alphaeus), Simon (a member of the Zealots, a subversive political party), Judas (son of James), Judas Iscariot (who later betrayed him).

16.verse: Here are their names: Simon (he also called him Peter), Andrew (Simon’s brother), James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James (the son of Alphaeus), Simon (a member of the Zealots, a subversive political party), Judas (son of James), Judas Iscariot (who later betrayed him).

17.verse: When they came down the slopes of the mountain, they stood with Jesus on a large, level area, surrounded by many of his followers who, in turn, were surrounded by the crowds. For people from all over Judea and from Jerusalem and from as far north as the seacoasts of Tyre and Sidon had come to hear him or to be healed. And he cast out many demons.

18.verse: When they came down the slopes of the mountain, they stood with Jesus on a large, level area, surrounded by many of his followers who, in turn, were surrounded by the crowds. For people from all over Judea and from Jerusalem and from as far north as the seacoasts of Tyre and Sidon had come to hear him or to be healed. And he cast out many demons.

19.verse: Everyone was trying to touch him, for when they did, healing power went out from him and they were cured.

20.verse: Then he turned to his disciples and said, “What happiness there is for you who are poor, for the Kingdom of God is yours!

21.verse: What happiness there is for you who are now hungry, for you are going to be satisfied! What happiness there is for you who weep, for the time will come when you shall laugh with joy!

22.verse: What happiness it is when others hate you and exclude you and insult you and smear your name because you are mine!

23.verse: When that happens, rejoice! Yes, leap for joy! For you will have a great reward awaiting you in heaven. And you will be in good company—the ancient prophets were treated that way too!

24.verse: “But, oh, the sorrows that await the rich. For they have their only happiness down here.

25.verse: They are fat and prosperous now, but a time of awful hunger is before them. Their careless laughter now means sorrow then.

26.verse: And what sadness is ahead for those praised by the crowds—for false prophets have always been praised.

27.verse: “Listen, all of you. Love your enemies. Do good to those who hate you.

28.verse: Pray for the happiness of those who curse you; implore God’s blessing on those who hurt you.

29.verse: “If someone slaps you on one cheek, let him slap the other too! If someone demands your coat, give him your shirt besides.

30.verse: Give what you have to anyone who asks you for it; and when things are taken away from you, don’t worry about getting them back.

31.verse: Treat others as you want them to treat you.

32.verse: “Do you think you deserve credit for merely loving those who love you? Even the godless do that!

33.verse: And if you do good only to those who do you good—is that so wonderful? Even sinners do that much!

34.verse: And if you lend money only to those who can repay you, what good is that? Even the most wicked will lend to their own kind for full return!

35.verse: “Love your enemies! Do good to them! Lend to them! And don’t be concerned about the fact that they won’t repay. Then your reward from heaven will be very great, and you will truly be acting as sons of God: for he is kind to the unthankful and to those who are very wicked.

36.verse: “Try to show as much compassion as your Father does.

37.verse: “Never criticize or condemn—or it will all come back on you. Go easy on others; then they will do the same for you.

38.verse: For if you give, you will get! Your gift will return to you in full and overflowing measure, pressed down, shaken together to make room for more, and running over. Whatever measure you use to give—large or small—will be used to measure what is given back to you.”

39.verse: Here are some of the story-illustrations Jesus used in his sermons: “What good is it for one blind man to lead another? He will fall into a ditch and pull the other down with him.

40.verse: How can a student know more than his teacher? But if he works hard, he may learn as much.

41.verse: “And why quibble about the speck in someone else’s eye—his little fault—when a board is in your own?

42.verse: How can you think of saying to him, ‘Brother, let me help you get rid of that speck in your eye,’ when you can’t see past the board in yours? Hypocrite! First get rid of the board, and then perhaps you can see well enough to deal with his speck!

43.verse: “A tree from good stock doesn’t produce scrub fruit nor do trees from poor stock produce choice fruit.

44.verse: A tree is identified by the kind of fruit it produces. Figs never grow on thorns, or grapes on bramble bushes.

45.verse: A good man produces good deeds from a good heart. And an evil man produces evil deeds from his hidden wickedness. Whatever is in the heart overflows into speech.

46.verse: “So why do you call me ‘Lord’ when you won’t obey me?

47.verse: But all those who come and listen and obey me are like a man who builds a house on a strong foundation laid upon the underlying rock. When the floodwaters rise and break against the house, it stands firm, for it is strongly built.

48.verse: But all those who come and listen and obey me are like a man who builds a house on a strong foundation laid upon the underlying rock. When the floodwaters rise and break against the house, it stands firm, for it is strongly built.

49.verse: “But those who listen and don’t obey are like a man who builds a house without a foundation. When the floods sweep down against that house, it crumbles into a heap of ruins.”

1.verse: When Jesus had finished his sermon he went back into the city of Capernaum.

2.verse: Just at that time the highly prized slave of a Roman army captain was sick and near death.

3.verse: When the captain heard about Jesus, he sent some respected Jewish elders to ask him to come and heal his slave.

4.verse: So they began pleading earnestly with Jesus to come with them and help the man. They told him what a wonderful person the captain was. “If anyone deserves your help, it is he,” they said,

5.verse: “for he loves the Jews and even paid personally to build us a synagogue!”

6.verse: Jesus went with them; but just before arriving at the house, the captain sent some friends to say, “Sir, don’t inconvenience yourself by coming to my home, for I am not worthy of any such honor or even to come and meet you. Just speak a word from where you are, and my servant boy will be healed! I know, because I am under the authority of my superior officers, and I have authority over my men. I only need to say ‘Go!’ and they go; or ‘Come!’ and they come; and to my slave, ‘Do this or that,’ and he does it. So just say, ‘Be healed!’ and my servant will be well again!”

7.verse: Jesus went with them; but just before arriving at the house, the captain sent some friends to say, “Sir, don’t inconvenience yourself by coming to my home, for I am not worthy of any such honor or even to come and meet you. Just speak a word from where you are, and my servant boy will be healed! I know, because I am under the authority of my superior officers, and I have authority over my men. I only need to say ‘Go!’ and they go; or ‘Come!’ and they come; and to my slave, ‘Do this or that,’ and he does it. So just say, ‘Be healed!’ and my servant will be well again!”

8.verse: Jesus went with them; but just before arriving at the house, the captain sent some friends to say, “Sir, don’t inconvenience yourself by coming to my home, for I am not worthy of any such honor or even to come and meet you. Just speak a word from where you are, and my servant boy will be healed! I know, because I am under the authority of my superior officers, and I have authority over my men. I only need to say ‘Go!’ and they go; or ‘Come!’ and they come; and to my slave, ‘Do this or that,’ and he does it. So just say, ‘Be healed!’ and my servant will be well again!”

9.verse: Jesus was amazed. Turning to the crowd he said, “Never among all the Jews in Israel have I met a man with faith like this.”

10.verse: And when the captain’s friends returned to his house, they found the slave completely healed.

11.verse: Not long afterwards Jesus went with his disciples to the village of Nain, with the usual great crowd at his heels.

12.verse: A funeral procession was coming out as he approached the village gate. The boy who had died was the only son of his widowed mother, and many mourners from the village were with her.

13.verse: When the Lord saw her, his heart overflowed with sympathy. “Don’t cry!” he said.

14.verse: Then he walked over to the coffin and touched it, and the bearers stopped. “Laddie,” he said, “come back to life again.”

15.verse: Then the boy sat up and began to talk to those around him! And Jesus gave him back to his mother.

16.verse: A great fear swept the crowd, and they exclaimed with praises to God, “A mighty prophet has risen among us,” and, “We have seen the hand of God at work today.”

17.verse: The report of what he did that day raced from end to end of Judea and even out across the borders.

18.verse: The disciples of John the Baptist soon heard of all that Jesus was doing. When they told John about it,

19.verse: he sent two of his disciples to Jesus to ask him, “Are you really the Messiah? Or shall we keep on looking for him?”

20.verse: The two disciples found Jesus while he was curing many sick people of their various diseases—healing the lame and the blind and casting out evil spirits. When they asked him John’s question, this was his reply: “Go back to John and tell him all you have seen and heard here today: how those who were blind can see. The lame are walking without a limp. The lepers are completely healed. The deaf can hear again. The dead come back to life. And the poor are hearing the Good News.

21.verse: The two disciples found Jesus while he was curing many sick people of their various diseases—healing the lame and the blind and casting out evil spirits. When they asked him John’s question, this was his reply: “Go back to John and tell him all you have seen and heard here today: how those who were blind can see. The lame are walking without a limp. The lepers are completely healed. The deaf can hear again. The dead come back to life. And the poor are hearing the Good News.

22.verse: The two disciples found Jesus while he was curing many sick people of their various diseases—healing the lame and the blind and casting out evil spirits. When they asked him John’s question, this was his reply: “Go back to John and tell him all you have seen and heard here today: how those who were blind can see. The lame are walking without a limp. The lepers are completely healed. The deaf can hear again. The dead come back to life. And the poor are hearing the Good News.

23.verse: And tell him, ‘Blessed is the one who does not lose his faith in me.’”

24.verse: After they left, Jesus talked to the crowd about John. “Who is this man you went out into the Judean wilderness to see?” he asked. “Did you find him weak as grass, moved by every breath of wind?

25.verse: Did you find him dressed in expensive clothes? No! Men who live in luxury are found in palaces, not out in the wilderness.

26.verse: But did you find a prophet? Yes! And more than a prophet.

27.verse: He is the one to whom the Scriptures refer when they say, ‘Look! I am sending my messenger ahead of you, to prepare the way before you.’

28.verse: In all humanity there is no one greater than John. And yet the least citizen of the Kingdom of God is greater than he.”

29.verse: And all who heard John preach—even the most wicked of them—agreed that God’s requirements were right, and they were baptized by him.

30.verse: All, that is, except the Pharisees and teachers of Moses’ law. They rejected God’s plan for them and refused John’s baptism.

31.verse: “What can I say about such men?” Jesus asked. “With what shall I compare them?

32.verse: They are like a group of children who complain to their friends, ‘You don’t like it if we play “wedding” and you don’t like it if we play “funeral”!’

33.verse: For John the Baptist used to go without food and never took a drop of liquor all his life, and you said, ‘He must be crazy!’

34.verse: But I eat my food and drink my wine, and you say, ‘What a glutton Jesus is! And he drinks! And has the lowest sort of friends!’

35.verse: But I am sure you can always justify your inconsistencies.”

36.verse: One of the Pharisees asked Jesus to come to his home for lunch and Jesus accepted the invitation. As they sat down to eat,

37.verse: a woman of the streets—a prostitute—heard he was there and brought an exquisite flask filled with expensive perfume.

38.verse: Going in, she knelt behind him at his feet, weeping, with her tears falling down upon his feet; and she wiped them off with her hair and kissed them and poured the perfume on them.

39.verse: When Jesus’ host, a Pharisee, saw what was happening and who the woman was, he said to himself, “This proves that Jesus is no prophet, for if God had really sent him, he would know what kind of woman this one is!”

40.verse: Then Jesus spoke up and answered his thoughts. “Simon,” he said to the Pharisee, “I have something to say to you.” “All right, Teacher,” Simon replied, “go ahead.”

41.verse: Then Jesus told him this story: “A man loaned money to two people—$5,000 to one and $500 to the other.

42.verse: But neither of them could pay him back, so he kindly forgave them both, letting them keep the money! Which do you suppose loved him most after that?”

43.verse: “I suppose the one who had owed him the most,” Simon answered. “Correct,” Jesus agreed.

44.verse: Then he turned to the woman and said to Simon, “Look! See this woman kneeling here! When I entered your home, you didn’t bother to offer me water to wash the dust from my feet, but she has washed them with her tears and wiped them with her hair.

45.verse: You refused me the customary kiss of greeting, but she has kissed my feet again and again from the time I first came in.

46.verse: You neglected the usual courtesy of olive oil to anoint my head, but she has covered my feet with rare perfume.

47.verse: Therefore her sins—and they are many—are forgiven, for she loved me much; but one who is forgiven little, shows little love.”

48.verse: And he said to her, “Your sins are forgiven.”

49.verse: Then the men at the table said to themselves, “Who does this man think he is, going around forgiving sins?”

50.verse: And Jesus said to the woman, “Your faith has saved you; go in peace.”

1.verse: Not long afterwards he began a tour of the cities and villages of Galilee to announce the coming of the Kingdom of God, and took his twelve disciples with him.

2.verse: Some women went along, from whom he had cast out demons or whom he had healed; among them were Mary Magdalene (Jesus had cast out seven demons from her),

3.verse: Joanna, Chuza’s wife (Chuza was King Herod’s business manager and was in charge of his palace and domestic affairs), Susanna, and many others who were contributing from their private means to the support of Jesus and his disciples.

4.verse: One day he gave this illustration to a large crowd that was gathering to hear him—while many others were still on the way, coming from other towns.

5.verse: “A farmer went out to his field to sow grain. As he scattered the seed on the ground, some of it fell on a footpath and was trampled on; and the birds came and ate it as it lay exposed.

6.verse: Other seed fell on shallow soil with rock beneath. This seed began to grow, but soon withered and died for lack of moisture.

7.verse: Other seed landed in thistle patches, and the young grain stalks were soon choked out.

8.verse: Still other fell on fertile soil; this seed grew and produced a crop one hundred times as large as he had planted.” (As he was giving this illustration he said, “If anyone has listening ears, use them now!”)

9.verse: His apostles asked him what the story meant.

10.verse: He replied, “God has granted you to know the meaning of these parables, for they tell a great deal about the Kingdom of God. But these crowds hear the words and do not understand, just as the ancient prophets predicted.

11.verse: “This is its meaning: The seed is God’s message to men.

12.verse: The hard path where some seed fell represents the hard hearts of those who hear the words of God, but then the devil comes and steals the words away and prevents people from believing and being saved.

13.verse: The stony ground represents those who enjoy listening to sermons, but somehow the message never really gets through to them and doesn’t take root and grow. They know the message is true, and sort of believe for a while; but when the hot winds of persecution blow, they lose interest.

14.verse: The seed among the thorns represents those who listen and believe God’s words but whose faith afterwards is choked out by worry and riches and the responsibilities and pleasures of life. And so they are never able to help anyone else to believe the Good News.

15.verse: “But the good soil represents honest, good-hearted people. They listen to God’s words and cling to them and steadily spread them to others who also soon believe.”

16.verse: Another time he asked, “Who ever heard of someone lighting a lamp and then covering it up to keep it from shining? No, lamps are mounted in the open where they can be seen.

17.verse: This illustrates the fact that someday everything in men’s hearts shall be brought to light and made plain to all.

18.verse: So be careful how you listen; for whoever has, to him shall be given more; and whoever does not have, even what he thinks he has shall be taken away from him.”

19.verse: Once when his mother and brothers came to see him, they couldn’t get into the house where he was teaching because of the crowds.

20.verse: When Jesus heard they were standing outside and wanted to see him,

21.verse: he remarked, “My mother and my brothers are all those who hear the message of God and obey it.”

22.verse: One day about that time, as he and his disciples were out in a boat, he suggested that they cross to the other side of the lake.

23.verse: On the way across he lay down for a nap, and while he was sleeping the wind began to rise. A fierce storm developed that threatened to swamp them, and they were in real danger.

24.verse: They rushed over and woke him up. “Master, Master, we are sinking!” they screamed. So he spoke to the storm: “Quiet down,” he said, and the wind and waves subsided and all was calm!

25.verse: Then he asked them, “Where is your faith?” And they were filled with awe and fear of him and said to one another, “Who is this man, that even the winds and waves obey him?”

26.verse: So they arrived at the other side, in the Gerasene country across the lake from Galilee.

27.verse: As he was climbing out of the boat a man from the city of Gadara came to meet him, a man who had been demon-possessed for a long time. Homeless and naked, he lived in a cemetery among the tombs.

28.verse: As soon as he saw Jesus, he shrieked and fell to the ground before him, screaming, “What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of God Most High? Please, I beg you, oh, don’t torment me!”

29.verse: For Jesus was already commanding the demon to leave him. This demon had often taken control of the man so that even when shackled with chains he simply broke them and rushed out into the desert, completely under the demon’s power.

30.verse: “What is your name?” Jesus asked the demon. “Legion,” they replied—for the man was filled with thousands of them!

31.verse: They kept begging Jesus not to order them into the Bottomless Pit.

32.verse: A herd of pigs was feeding on the mountainside nearby, and the demons pled with him to let them enter into the pigs. And Jesus said they could.

33.verse: So they left the man and went into the pigs, and immediately the whole herd rushed down the mountainside and fell over a cliff into the lake below, where they drowned.

34.verse: The herdsmen rushed away to the nearby city, spreading the news as they ran.

35.verse: Soon a crowd came out to see for themselves what had happened and saw the man who had been demon-possessed sitting quietly at Jesus’ feet, clothed and sane! And the whole crowd was badly frightened.

36.verse: Then those who had seen it happen told how the demon-possessed man had been healed.

37.verse: And everyone begged Jesus to go away and leave them alone (for a deep wave of fear had swept over them). So he returned to the boat and left, crossing back to the other side of the lake.

38.verse: The man who had been demon-possessed begged to go too, but Jesus said no.

39.verse: “Go back to your family,” he told him, “and tell them what a wonderful thing God has done for you.” So he went all through the city telling everyone about Jesus’ mighty miracle.

40.verse: On the other side of the lake the crowds received him with open arms, for they had been waiting for him.

41.verse: And now a man named Jairus, a leader of a Jewish synagogue, came and fell down at Jesus’ feet and begged him to come home with him,

42.verse: for his only child was dying, a little girl twelve years old. Jesus went with him, pushing through the crowds.

43.verse: As they went a woman who wanted to be healed came up behind and touched him, for she had been slowly bleeding for twelve years, and could find no cure (though she had spent everything she had on doctors). But the instant she touched the edge of his robe, the bleeding stopped.

44.verse: As they went a woman who wanted to be healed came up behind and touched him, for she had been slowly bleeding for twelve years, and could find no cure (though she had spent everything she had on doctors). But the instant she touched the edge of his robe, the bleeding stopped.

45.verse: “Who touched me?” Jesus asked. Everyone denied it, and Peter said, “Master, so many are crowding against you. . . . ”

46.verse: But Jesus told him, “No, it was someone who deliberately touched me, for I felt healing power go out from me.”

47.verse: When the woman realized that Jesus knew, she began to tremble and fell to her knees before him and told why she had touched him and that now she was well.

48.verse: “Daughter,” he said to her, “your faith has healed you. Go in peace.”

49.verse: While he was still speaking to her, a messenger arrived from the Jairus’s home with the news that the little girl was dead. “She’s gone,” he told her father; “there’s no use troubling the Teacher now.”

50.verse: But when Jesus heard what had happened, he said to the father, “Don’t be afraid! Just trust me, and she’ll be all right.”

51.verse: When they arrived at the house, Jesus wouldn’t let anyone into the room except Peter, James, John, and the little girl’s father and mother.

52.verse: The home was filled with mourning people, but he said, “Stop the weeping! She isn’t dead; she is only asleep!”

53.verse: This brought scoffing and laughter, for they all knew she was dead.

54.verse: Then he took her by the hand and called, “Get up, little girl!”

55.verse: And at that moment her life returned and she jumped up! “Give her something to eat!” he said.

56.verse: Her parents were overcome with happiness, but Jesus insisted that they not tell anyone the details of what had happened.

1.verse: One day Jesus called together his twelve apostles and gave them authority over all demons—power to cast them out—and to heal all diseases.

2.verse: Then he sent them away to tell everyone about the coming of the Kingdom of God and to heal the sick.

3.verse: “Don’t even take along a walking stick,” he instructed them, “nor a beggar’s bag, nor food, nor money. Not even an extra coat.

4.verse: Be a guest in only one home at each village.

5.verse: “If the people of a town won’t listen to you when you enter it, turn around and leave, demonstrating God’s anger against it by shaking its dust from your feet as you go.”

6.verse: So they began their circuit of the villages, preaching the Good News and healing the sick.

7.verse: When reports of Jesus’ miracles reached Herod, the governor, he was worried and puzzled, for some were saying, “This is John the Baptist come back to life again”;

8.verse: and others, “It is Elijah or some other ancient prophet risen from the dead.” These rumors were circulating all over the land.

9.verse: “I beheaded John,” Herod said, “so who is this man about whom I hear such strange stories?” And he tried to see him.

10.verse: After the apostles returned to Jesus and reported what they had done, he slipped quietly away with them toward the city of Bethsaida.

11.verse: But the crowds found out where he was going and followed. And he welcomed them, teaching them again about the Kingdom of God and curing those who were ill.

12.verse: Late in the afternoon all twelve of the disciples came and urged him to send the people away to the nearby villages and farms, to find food and lodging for the night. “For there is nothing to eat here in this deserted spot,” they said.

13.verse: But Jesus replied, “You feed them!” “Why, we have only five loaves of bread and two fish among the lot of us,” they protested; “or are you expecting us to go and buy enough for this whole mob?”

14.verse: For there were about 5,000 men there! “Just tell them to sit down on the ground in groups of about fifty each,” Jesus replied.

15.verse: So they did.

16.verse: Jesus took the five loaves and two fish and looked up into the sky and gave thanks; then he broke off pieces for his disciples to set before the crowd.

17.verse: And everyone ate and ate; still, twelve basketfuls of scraps were picked up afterwards!

18.verse: One day as he was alone, praying, with his disciples nearby, he came over and asked them, “Who are the people saying I am?”

19.verse: “John the Baptist,” they told him, “or perhaps Elijah or one of the other ancient prophets risen from the dead.”

20.verse: Then he asked them, “Who do you think I am?” Peter replied, “The Messiah—the Christ of God!”

21.verse: He gave them strict orders not to speak of this to anyone.

22.verse: “For I, the Messiah, must suffer much,” he said, “and be rejected by the Jewish leaders—the elders, chief priests, and teachers of the Law—and be killed; and three days later I will come back to life again!”

23.verse: Then he said to all, “Anyone who wants to follow me must put aside his own desires and conveniences and carry his cross with him every day and keep close to me!

24.verse: Whoever loses his life for my sake will save it, but whoever insists on keeping his life will lose it;

25.verse: and what profit is there in gaining the whole world when it means forfeiting one’s self?

26.verse: “When I, the Messiah, come in my glory and in the glory of the Father and the holy angels, I will be ashamed then of all who are ashamed of me and of my words now.

27.verse: But this is the simple truth—some of you who are standing here right now will not die until you have seen the Kingdom of God.”

28.verse: Eight days later he took Peter, James, and John with him into the hills to pray.

29.verse: And as he was praying, his face began to shine, and his clothes became dazzling white and blazed with light.

30.verse: Then two men appeared and began talking with him—Moses and Elijah!

31.verse: They were splendid in appearance, glorious to see; and they were speaking of his death at Jerusalem, to be carried out in accordance with God’s plan.

32.verse: Peter and the others had been very drowsy and had fallen asleep. Now they woke up and saw Jesus covered with brightness and glory, and the two men standing with him.

33.verse: As Moses and Elijah were starting to leave, Peter, all confused and not even knowing what he was saying, blurted out, “Master, this is wonderful! We’ll put up three shelters—one for you and one for Moses and one for Elijah!”

34.verse: But even as he was saying this, a bright cloud formed above them; and terror gripped them as it covered them.

35.verse: And a voice from the cloud said, “This is my Son, my Chosen One; listen to him.”

36.verse: Then, as the voice died away, Jesus was there alone with his disciples. They didn’t tell anyone what they had seen until long afterwards.

37.verse: The next day as they descended from the hill, a huge crowd met him,

38.verse: and a man in the crowd called out to him, “Teacher, this boy here is my only son,

39.verse: and a demon keeps seizing him, making him scream; and it throws him into convulsions so that he foams at the mouth; it is always hitting him and hardly ever leaves him alone.

40.verse: I begged your disciples to cast the demon out, but they couldn’t.”

41.verse: “O you stubborn faithless people,” Jesus said to his disciples, “how long should I put up with you? Bring him here.”

42.verse: As the boy was coming the demon knocked him to the ground and threw him into a violent convulsion. But Jesus ordered the demon to come out, and healed the boy and handed him over to his father.

43.verse: Awe gripped the people as they saw this display of the power of God. Meanwhile, as they were exclaiming over all the wonderful things he was doing, Jesus said to his disciples,

44.verse: “Listen to me and remember what I say. I, the Messiah, am going to be betrayed.”

45.verse: But the disciples didn’t know what he meant, for their minds had been sealed and they were afraid to ask him.

46.verse: Now came an argument among them as to which of them would be greatest in the coming Kingdom!

47.verse: But Jesus knew their thoughts, so he stood a little child beside him

48.verse: and said to them, “Anyone who takes care of a little child like this is caring for me! And whoever cares for me is caring for God who sent me. Your care for others is the measure of your greatness.”

49.verse: His disciple John came to him and said, “Master, we saw someone using your name to cast out demons. And we told him not to. After all, he isn’t in our group.”

50.verse: But Jesus said, “You shouldn’t have done that! For anyone who is not against you is for you.”

51.verse: As the time drew near for his return to heaven, he moved steadily onward toward Jerusalem with an iron will.

52.verse: One day he sent messengers ahead to reserve rooms for them in a Samaritan village.

53.verse: But they were turned away! The people of the village refused to have anything to do with them because they were headed for Jerusalem.

54.verse: When word came back of what had happened, James and John said to Jesus, “Master, shall we order fire down from heaven to burn them up?”

55.verse: But Jesus turned and rebuked them,

56.verse: and they went on to another village.

57.verse: As they were walking along someone said to Jesus, “I will always follow you no matter where you go.”

58.verse: But Jesus replied, “Remember, I don’t even own a place to lay my head. Foxes have dens to live in, and birds have nests, but I, the Messiah, have no earthly home at all.”

59.verse: Another time, when he invited a man to come with him and to be his disciple, the man agreed—but wanted to wait until his father’s death.

60.verse: Jesus replied, “Let those without eternal life concern themselves with things like that. Your duty is to come and preach the coming of the Kingdom of God to all the world.”

61.verse: Another said, “Yes, Lord, I will come, but first let me ask permission of those at home.”

62.verse: But Jesus told him, “Anyone who lets himself be distracted from the work I plan for him is not fit for the Kingdom of God.”

1.verse: The Lord now chose seventy other disciples and sent them on ahead in pairs to all the towns and villages he planned to visit later.

2.verse: These were his instructions to them: “Plead with the Lord of the harvest to send out more laborers to help you, for the harvest is so plentiful and the workers so few.

3.verse: Go now, and remember that I am sending you out as lambs among wolves.

4.verse: Don’t take any money with you, or a beggar’s bag, or even an extra pair of shoes. And don’t waste time along the way.

5.verse: “Whenever you enter a home, give it your blessing.

6.verse: If it is worthy of the blessing, the blessing will stand; if not, the blessing will return to you.

7.verse: “When you enter a village, don’t shift around from home to home, but stay in one place, eating and drinking without question whatever is set before you. And don’t hesitate to accept hospitality, for the workman is worthy of his wages!

8.verse: “If a town welcomes you, follow these two rules: (1) Eat whatever is set before you. (2) Heal the sick; and as you heal them, say, ‘The Kingdom of God is very near you now.’

9.verse: “If a town welcomes you, follow these two rules: (1) Eat whatever is set before you. (2) Heal the sick; and as you heal them, say, ‘The Kingdom of God is very near you now.’

10.verse: “But if a town refuses you, go out into its streets and say,

11.verse: ‘We wipe the dust of your town from our feet as a public announcement of your doom. Never forget how close you were to the Kingdom of God!’

12.verse: Even wicked Sodom will be better off than such a city on the Judgment Day.

13.verse: What horrors await you, you cities of Chorazin and Bethsaida! For if the miracles I did for you had been done in the cities of Tyre and Sidon, their people would have sat in deep repentance long ago, clothed in sackcloth and throwing ashes on their heads to show their remorse.

14.verse: Yes, Tyre and Sidon will receive less punishment on the Judgment Day than you.

15.verse: And you people of Capernaum, what shall I say about you? Will you be exalted to heaven? No, you shall be brought down to hell.”

16.verse: Then he said to the disciples, “Those who welcome you are welcoming me. And those who reject you are rejecting me. And those who reject me are rejecting God who sent me.”

17.verse: When the seventy disciples returned, they joyfully reported to him, “Even the demons obey us when we use your name.”

18.verse: “Yes,” he told them, “I saw Satan falling from heaven as a flash of lightning!

19.verse: And I have given you authority over all the power of the Enemy, and to walk among serpents and scorpions and to crush them. Nothing shall injure you!

20.verse: However, the important thing is not that demons obey you, but that your names are registered as citizens of heaven.”

21.verse: Then he was filled with the joy of the Holy Spirit and said, “I praise you, O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, for hiding these things from the intellectuals and worldly wise and for revealing them to those who are as trusting as little children. Yes, thank you, Father, for that is the way you wanted it.

22.verse: I am the Agent of my Father in everything; and no one really knows the Son except the Father, and no one really knows the Father except the Son and those to whom the Son chooses to reveal him.”

23.verse: Then, turning to the twelve disciples, he said quietly, “How privileged you are to see what you have seen.

24.verse: Many a prophet and king of old has longed for these days, to see and hear what you have seen and heard!”

25.verse: One day an expert on Moses’ laws came to test Jesus’ orthodoxy by asking him this question: “Teacher, what does a man need to do to live forever in heaven?”

26.verse: Jesus replied, “What does Moses’ law say about it?”

27.verse: “It says,” he replied, “that you must love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your strength, and with all your mind. And you must love your neighbor just as much as you love yourself.”

28.verse: “Right!” Jesus told him. “Do this and you shall live!”

29.verse: The man wanted to justify his lack of love for some kinds of people, so he asked, “Which neighbors?”

30.verse: Jesus replied with an illustration: “A Jew going on a trip from Jerusalem to Jericho was attacked by bandits. They stripped him of his clothes and money, and beat him up and left him lying half dead beside the road.

31.verse: “By chance a Jewish priest came along; and when he saw the man lying there, he crossed to the other side of the road and passed him by.

32.verse: A Jewish Temple-assistant walked over and looked at him lying there, but then went on.

33.verse: “But a despised Samaritan came along, and when he saw him, he felt deep pity.

34.verse: Kneeling beside him the Samaritan soothed his wounds with medicine and bandaged them. Then he put the man on his donkey and walked along beside him till they came to an inn, where he nursed him through the night.

35.verse: The next day he handed the innkeeper two twenty-dollar bills and told him to take care of the man. ‘If his bill runs higher than that,’ he said, ‘I’ll pay the difference the next time I am here.’

36.verse: “Now which of these three would you say was a neighbor to the bandits’ victim?”

37.verse: The man replied, “The one who showed him some pity.” Then Jesus said, “Yes, now go and do the same.”

38.verse: As Jesus and the disciples continued on their way to Jerusalem they came to a village where a woman named Martha welcomed them into her home.

39.verse: Her sister Mary sat on the floor, listening to Jesus as he talked.

40.verse: But Martha was the jittery type and was worrying over the big dinner she was preparing. She came to Jesus and said, “Sir, doesn’t it seem unfair to you that my sister just sits here while I do all the work? Tell her to come and help me.”

41.verse: But the Lord said to her, “Martha, dear friend, you are so upset over all these details!

42.verse: There is really only one thing worth being concerned about. Mary has discovered it—and I won’t take it away from her!”

1.verse: Once when Jesus had been out praying, one of his disciples came to him as he finished and said, “Lord, teach us a prayer to recite just as John taught one to his disciples.”

2.verse: And this is the prayer he taught them: “Father, may your name be honored for its holiness; send your Kingdom soon.

3.verse: Give us our food day by day.

4.verse: And forgive our sins—for we have forgiven those who sinned against us. And don’t allow us to be tempted.”

5.verse: Then, teaching them more about prayer, he used this illustration: “Suppose you went to a friend’s house at midnight, wanting to borrow three loaves of bread. You would shout up to him, ‘A friend of mine has just arrived for a visit and I’ve nothing to give him to eat.’

6.verse: Then, teaching them more about prayer, he used this illustration: “Suppose you went to a friend’s house at midnight, wanting to borrow three loaves of bread. You would shout up to him, ‘A friend of mine has just arrived for a visit and I’ve nothing to give him to eat.’

7.verse: He would call down from his bedroom, ‘Please don’t ask me to get up. The door is locked for the night and we are all in bed. I just can’t help you this time.’

8.verse: “But I’ll tell you this—though he won’t do it as a friend, if you keep knocking long enough, he will get up and give you everything you want—just because of your persistence.

9.verse: And so it is with prayer—keep on asking and you will keep on getting; keep on looking and you will keep on finding; knock and the door will be opened.

10.verse: Everyone who asks, receives; all who seek, find; and the door is opened to everyone who knocks.

11.verse: “You men who are fathers—if your boy asks for bread, do you give him a stone? If he asks for fish, do you give him a snake?

12.verse: If he asks for an egg, do you give him a scorpion? Of course not!

13.verse: “And if even sinful persons like yourselves give children what they need, don’t you realize that your heavenly Father will do at least as much, and give the Holy Spirit to those who ask for him?”

14.verse: Once, when Jesus cast out a demon from a man who couldn’t speak, his voice returned to him. The crowd was excited and enthusiastic,

15.verse: but some said, “No wonder he can cast them out. He gets his power from Satan, the king of demons!”

16.verse: Others asked for something to happen in the sky to prove his claim of being the Messiah.

17.verse: He knew the thoughts of each of them, so he said, “Any kingdom filled with civil war is doomed; so is a home filled with argument and strife.

18.verse: Therefore, if what you say is true, that Satan is fighting against himself by empowering me to cast out his demons, how can his kingdom survive?

19.verse: And if I am empowered by Satan, what about your own followers? For they cast out demons! Do you think this proves they are possessed by Satan? Ask them if you are right!

20.verse: But if I am casting out demons because of power from God, it proves that the Kingdom of God has arrived.

21.verse: “For when Satan, strong and fully armed, guards his palace, it is safe—

22.verse: until someone stronger and better armed attacks and overcomes him and strips him of his weapons and carries off his belongings.

23.verse: “Anyone who is not for me is against me; if he isn’t helping me, he is hurting my cause.

24.verse: “When a demon is cast out of a man, it goes to the deserts, searching there for rest; but finding none, it returns to the person it left,

25.verse: and finds that its former home is all swept and clean.

26.verse: Then it goes and gets seven other demons more evil than itself, and they all enter the man. And so the poor fellow is seven times worse off than he was before.”

27.verse: As he was speaking, a woman in the crowd called out, “God bless your mother—the womb from which you came, and the breasts that gave you suck!”

28.verse: He replied, “Yes, but even more blessed are all who hear the Word of God and put it into practice.”

29.verse: As the crowd pressed in upon him, he preached them this sermon: “These are evil times, with evil people. They keep asking for some strange happening in the skies to prove I am the Messiah, but the only proof I will give them is a miracle like that of Jonah, whose experiences proved to the people of Nineveh that God had sent him. My similar experience will prove that God has sent me to these people.
